title: Bosnia and Herzegovina - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: On 3 February 2021, around 30 parents protested in front of the elementary school in Potocari, Bosnia and Herzegovina, because the school has no heating. [size=around 30]
On 2 February 2021, around 20 people protested and blocked the entrance to a local landfill in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, claiming that it operates without a license. [size=around 20]

On 30 January 2021, parents of children attending an elementary school in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, protested demanding the resignation of Education Minister because (as they claim) nepotism leads to frequent fluctuation of teachers in the school. [size=no report]

On 27 January 2021, football fans protested in front of the Football Association in Sarajevo-Novi Grad, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against the choice of the new selector of the representation. [size=no report]

On 25 January 2021, thousands of health workers protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding better job security and working conditions through a collective contract. Two men physically attacked the protesters while they marched. [size=thousands]
On 25 January 2021, local residents protested in Bihac, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against migrants and refugees being housed in their area. [size=no report]

On 15 January 2021, several thousand medical workers protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding better job security and working conditions through a collective contract. [size=several thousand]

On 14 January 2021, around 50 entrepreneurs protested at the Crnaja tunnel (coded to Jablanica, Bosnia and Herzegovina) because the tunnel is due to be closed for reconstruction and they are worried it will affect their business. [size=around 50]

On 5 January 2021, several hundred health workers protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding better job security and better work conditions through a collective contract. [size=several hundred]

On 3 January 2021, migrants and refugees protested in the camp near Bihac, Bosnia and Herzegovina, during the visit of the country's Security Minister demanding help from international organizations and the state. The camp burned down in December 2020, and the people were left with no shelter. [size=no report]
On 1 January 2021, local residents protested in Morancani, Bosnia and Herzegovina, because of frequent electricity outages. [size=no report]

On 1 January 2021, around 200 migrants and refugees protested at the camp near Bihac, Bosnia and Herzegovina, because they have been stranded outdoors as one camp burned down a week earlier and the other won't accept them. [size=around 200]
On 31 December 2020, several hundred local residents protested at the camp near Bihac, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against migrants and refugees being placed at the camp. [size=several hundred]
On 30 December 2020, local residents protested in Bradina, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against migrants and refugees being placed in their area. [size=no report]
On 28 December 2020, hundreds of farmers protested near the border crossing in Gradiska, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding control of import of agricultural goods. [size=hundreds]
On 27 December 2020, approximately 40 local residents protested in Ilidza, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against migrants and refugees being placed in their area. [size=approximately 40]
On 25 December 2020, a group of citizens protested in Sanski Most, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against abuse and abandonment of dogs. [size=no report]
SNSD: Alliance of Independent Social Democrats

On 24 December 2020, several hundred SNSD supporters blocked the road in Doboj, Bosnia and Herzegovina, after the Central Electoral Commission did not confirm SNSD's victory in local elections. [size=several hundred]

On 24 December 2020, more than 200 health workers protested in Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding better work security and equal workers' rights through a collective contract. [size=more than 200]
On 23 December 2020, local residents protested in Bihac, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against a migrant detention center in their city. [size=no report]
On 22 December 2020, workers of the telecommunication company protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding better work security. [size=no report]
On 18 December 2020, health workers protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding a collective agreement, which would give them better labour rights. [size=no report]

On 18 December 2020, employees of a bus company protested in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, claiming the city's selection of a transport company to work with has not been transparent. [size=no report]

On 18 December 2020, activists of Justice for David marched through Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, to mark 1000 days since David's death. David was a young man whose death sparked protests after his family accused the police of covering up the circumstances. [size=no report]

On 11 December 2020, a group of women's rights activists protested in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in solidarity with the protests in Poland and to demand abortion be kept legal and safe. [size=no report]
On 10 December 2020, activists of ''Justice for David'' protested in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against the head of the top judicial body in the country. [size=no report]
On 9 December 2020, whistle-blowers and other protesters marched through Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against corruption. [size=no report]
On 7 December 2020, Croats from Teslic protested in Sarajevo-Novi Grad, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against what they claim is an electoral fraud on recent local elections in their town. [size=no report]

On 6 December 2020, ethic Croats protested in Gornji Vakuf-Uskoplje, Bosnia and Herzegovina, after the electoral commission decided to stop counting mail-in ballots. They believe this prevented the Croatian candidate from winning the local election. [size=no report]
Former Military Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina (2018-)

Mass grave: Around 3 December 2020, as reported, remains of 5 people, believed to be ethnic Serbs killed by Bosniaks during the war in 1995, were found in a mass grave near Sanski Most, Bosnia and Herzegovina.

On 23 November 2020, around 100 people, mostly from the hospitality industry, protested against new measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus in Brcko, Bosnia and Herzegovina. [size=around 100]
On 23 November 2020, local residents protested in Ilidza, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against migrants after a man was murdered, allegedly by a refugee. [size=no report]
On 22 November 2020, people protested in Bihac, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding the movement of migrants and refugees be contained to the camp. [size=no report]
On 21 November 2020, approximately 100 people protested in Ilidza, Bosnia and Herzegovina, after a local man was allegedly killed in a fight with migrants a few days earlier. [size=approximately 100]
On 19 November 2020, a protest against migrants and refugees was held in Hadzici, Bosnia and Herzegovina, after a man was allegedly killed in a fight with a migrant. [size=no report]
On 18 November 2020, several hundred people protested in Ilidza, Bosnia and Herzegovina, after a local man was allegedly killed in a fight with a migrant. [size=several hundred]
On 16 November 2020, several hundred NiP activists protested in Ilijas, Bosnia and Herzegovina, disputing the results of local election and demanding a recount. [size=several hundred]
PDP: Party of Democratic Progress; SDS: Serb Democratic Party

On 15 November 2020, activists of several oppositional parties, including SDS and PDP, protested in Doboj, Bosnia and Herzegovina, because their members were not allowed to monitor the local election. [size=no report]

On 14 November 2020, several hundred opponents of the ruling party SNSD protested in Trebinje, Bosnia and Herzegovina, claiming SNSD has been bribing voters ahead of the local elections. [size=several hundred]

On 13 November 2020, students protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding lower tuition fees and that they go back to in-person learning. Classes are currently held online due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]
On 13 November 2020, several hundred health workers protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding better working conditions. [size=several hundred]
On 7 November 2020, animal rights activists protested in Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding an end of killing of dogs in that city. [size=no report]
On 5 November 2020, health workers protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding higher wages and better working conditions. [size=no report]

On 4 November 2020, medical students marched through Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding lower tuition fees and scholarships, as well as going back to in-person learning. Practical seminars have been suspended due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 29 October 2020, approximately 20 owners of bars and restaurants protested against new, stricter measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus in Brcko, Bosnia and Herzegovina. [size=approximately 20]

On 28 October 2020, dozens of people protested against new, stricter measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina. Owners of cafes and restaurants, as well as musicians who are affected by the measures were prominently present. [size=dozens]

On 26 October 2020, people protested against new, stricter measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus in Bijeljina, Bosnia and Herzegovina. Owners of cafes and restaurants, as well as musicians who are affected by the measures were prominently present. [size=no report]
SNSD: Alliance of Independent Social Democrats

On 24 October 2020, an activist of SNSD was physically assaulted by the father of the candidate of a rival party (PDP) in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, for allegedly destroying her campaign posters.

On 14 October 2020, several hundred students protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding they go back to in-person learning despite the coronavirus pandemic and lower tuition fees. [size=several hundred]
On 13 October 2020, workers of a company protested in Lukavac, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding a new management after the company lost its environmental permit. [size=no report]

On 13 October 2020, 14 migrants and refugees reported that they were severely beaten by Croatian police during a push-back while they were trying to cross the border around Velika Kladusa, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Property destruction: On 10 October 2020, during the night, an unknown person or persons broke the windows of a mosque in the mostly Christian Orthodox town of Bijeljina, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
On 8 October 2020, high school students protested in Gorazde, Bosnia and Herzegovina, because of a lack of transport to school for students from rural areas. [size=no report]
On 4 October 2020, a group of citizens protested in Velika Kladusa, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding the closure of a local camp for migrants and refugees. [size=no report]
On 3 October 2020, residents of Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, protested against the local landfill, claiming it does not meet environmental standards. [size=no report]
On 1 October 2020, protesters gathered in Foca, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding a ban of construction of mini hydro power plants on their local river. [size=no report]
On 30 September 2020, protesters gathered in Sarajevo-Novo Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding a ban on construction of mini hydro power plants due to environmental reasons. [size=no report]

On 29 September 2020, workers of a company protested in Sarajevo-Centar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in protest after another company blocked off their premises in a property dispute, which left the workers of the first company unable to enter the building. [size=no report]

On 24 September 2020, approximately 20 family members of Bosnian women and children who are kept in Syrian camps after the fall of IS protested in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding they be deported back to Bosnia. [size=approximately 20]
On 24 September 2020, protesters gathered in Sarajevo-Novo Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding a ban on construction of mini hydro power plants due to environmental reasons. [size=no report]

On 22 September 2020, workers of a company protested in Sarajevo-Centar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in protest after another company blocked off their premises in a property dispute, which left the workers of the first company unable to enter the building. [size=no report]

On 18 September 2020, local residents protested in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, after an old cinema building was demolished. They claim new plans for the space are not in line with building regulations. [size=no report]

On 16 September 2020, workers of a company marched through Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in protest after another company blocked off their premises in a property dispute, which left the workers of the first company unable to enter the building. [size=no report]

On 14 September 2020, approximately 1000 parents protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding the children return to schools for in-person learning. Classes are currently held online due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=approximately 1000]

On 10 September 2020, activists of 'Justice for David' protested in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding the right to gather in the city's main square, which they have been banned from doing. [size=no report]

On 4 September 2020, several dozen cars participated in a vehicular protest drive through Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in solidarity with the Bosniaks who were attacked in Montenegro several days before. [size=several dozen]
On 29 August 2020, approximately 1000 people protested in Bihac, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against migrants and refugees, demanding they 'go home'. [size=approximately 1000]
On 29 August 2020, 100 activists of Platform for Progress protested in Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding, among other things, an ability to vote electronically. [size=100]

On 28 August 2020, local farmers protested in Odzak, Bosnia and Herzegovina, while their representative were in meeting with municipal officials, about management of state-owned agricultural land. [size=no report]
On 28 August 2020, local residents protested in Novi Grad, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against migrants and refugees being housed in their area. [size=no report]
On 23 August 2020, LGBTQI activists held a vehicular protest in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in lieu of a Pride March, alerting to the problems their community faces. [size=no report]
On 21 August 2020, around 500 farmers protested in Odzak, Bosnia and Herzegovina, because of management of a state-owned agricultural land. [size=around 500]
On 21 August 2020, an unspecified number of people protested in Tuzla, Bosnia and Herzegovina, after a teenager died due to what her parents said was a doctors' error. [size=no report]
On 20 August 2020, local residents protested in Velika Kladusa, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against migrants and refugees who are housed in camps in their area. [size=no report]
On 17 August 2020, an unspecified number of people protested in Gracanica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, after a teenager died due to what her parents said was a doctors' error. [size=no report]

On 16 August 2020, several hundred local residents protested and blocked the road against migrants and refugees being housed in their area in Velika Kladusa, Bosnia and Herzegovina. The protest was mostly peaceful but one demonstrator broke the windshield on a bus transporting refugees by throwing a rock. [size=several hundred]
On 15 August 2020, activists of Platform for Progress protested in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against political corruption and demanding a 'ministry of diaspora' be formed. [size=no report]
On 15 August 2020, local residents protested in Velika Kladusa, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against a new centre for migrants and refugees in their area. [size=no report]
On 11 August 2020, locals protested in Odzak, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding better management of state-owned agricultural land. [size=no report]

On 8 August 2020, local residents protested in Velika Kladusa, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding curfew be imposed on migrants and refugees who are housed in the city and a ban on alcohol sale for them. [size=no report]
On 7 August 2020, cititzens protested in Foca, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against construction of several mini hydro power plants on local rivers, due to environmental concerns. [size=no report]
On 4 August 2020, owners of cafes and restaurants protested in Drvar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against new restrictive measures imposed due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 30 July 2020, around 50 protesters, mostly workers of the service industry and musicians protested in Sarajevo-Centar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, because the working hours of cafes and restaurants in limited in order to stop the spread of the coronavirus. [size=around 50]
SSS: Independent Trade Unions of Bosnia and Herzegovina; Labour Group (Bosnia and Herzegovina)

On 27 July 2020, members of the Association of Independent Trade Unions marched through Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against changes to the Labour Law, which they said would take away workers' rights. 100 people attended the protest in order to respect measures against COVID19. [size=100]
On 22 July 2020, farmers from Odzaci, Bosnia and Herzegovina, protested and blocked the road because of management of state-owned agricultural land in that town. [size=no report]
On 15 July 2020, citizens of Sarajevo-Novi Grad, Bosnia and Herzegovina, protested against the construction in the place of an old hotel building, which is a city landmark. [size=no report]
On 10 July 2020, friends and family of a young man who had been murdered protested in Novi Travnik, Bosnia and Herzegovina, claiming the prison sentence his murderer got was too low. [size=no report]
On 9 July 2020, health workers protested in Sarajevo-Novo Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding a collective contract that will adjust their salary. [size=no report]

On 5 July 2020, more than 200 local residents protested in Drvar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, because textile waste from Italy, which was supposed to be housed there temporarily, has still not been removed. [size=more than 200]
On 4 July 2020, people protested in Sarajevo-Stari Grad, Bosnia and Herzegovina in front of the parliament because of corruption and 'criminal activities' within the government. [size=no report]

On 4 July 2020, approximately 100 local residents protested in Drvar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, because textile waste from Italy that was supposed to be there temporarily has not been removed. [size=approximately 100]

On 2 July 2020, workers from the tourist and hospitality industry protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding the borders, which are still closed due to the coronavirus, be open. [size=no report]

On 27 June 2020, 300 protesters marched in Bihac, Bosnia and Herzegovina, due to a number of issues, including the situations with migrants and refugees, toxic waste going into the river, and allowing diaspora seats in government. [size=300]
On 20 June 2020, several hundred protesters marched through Gorazde, Bosnia and Herzegovina to protest a wall being built on the bank of the river. [size=several hundred]
On 18 June 2020, an explosive device was activated on a street in Sarajevo-Novi Grad, Bosnia and Herzegovina. No one was injured but material damage was caused.

On 15 June 2020, residents of a neighbourhood in Sarajevo-Novo Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, protested in front of the Office of High Representative because of illegal construction in their neighbourhood. [size=no report]

On 13 June 2020, protesters marched through Tuzla, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding elections, fight against corruption, and better working conditions in the whole country. The number of protesters was limited to 100 due to COVID19. [size=100]

On 12 June 2020, protesters rallied in Sarajevo-Centar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in support of the head imam who recently resigned in face of hostile pressure from parts of the community. [size=no report]
On 11 June 2020, local residents protested in Vogosca, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against construction in their neighbourhood. [size=no report]
Mothers of Srebrenica; Women (Bosnia and Herzegovina)

On 11 June 2020, Mothers of Srebrenica protested in Potocari, Bosnia and Herzegovina, before the funeral of victims recently discovered in a mass grave. They called for faster uncovering of mass graves and identification of the victims. [size=no report]
On 6 June 2020, a protest of solidarity with Black Lives Matter following the killing of George Floyd was held in Tuzla, Bosnia and Herzegovina. [size=no report]
On 6 June 2020, protesters marched through Gorazde, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against a construction of a wall on a local river. [size=no report]
On 1 June 2020, hundreds protested in Goransko Polje, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against the construction of mini power plants on the local river due to environmental concerns. [size=hundreds]
On 31 May 2020, several dozen protesters protested at a commoration of the war-time killing of Muslims in Prijedor, Bosnia and Herzegovina. [size=several dozen]

On 30 May 2020, several thousand people marched through Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding the government step down after a series of corruption scandals. Leaders of several oppositional parties attended. [size=several thousand]

On 23 May 2020, family of a man who had been murdered, along with other fans of the football club he supported, protested in Bijeljina, Bosnia and Herzegovina, after the men who killed him were released early from prison. [size=no report]
On 21 May 2020, small business owners protested in Sarajevo-Centar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding subsidies from the government because of their losses due to the coronavirus. [size=no report]
Around 19 May 2020, local residents protested in Gracanica, Kosovo, because of water shortages and restrictions. [size=no report]

On 16 May 2020, a protest was held in Tuzla, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against a Catholic mass in Sarajevo, which was to commemorate Nazi-allied troops and civilians killed at the end of the Second World War. [size=no report]
On 16 May 2020, citizens of Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, protested demanding local elections. Mostar has not had local elections in 12 years. [size=no report]

On 16 May 2020, some 5000 protesters marched through Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against a Catholic mass being held to commemorate Croatian Nazi-allied troops and civilians who were killed at the end of the Second World War. [size=some 5000]

On 15 May 2020, between 50 and 100 people gathered in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, to 'commemorate victims of fascism' and show protest against a Catholic mass in Sarajevo, which commemorates Croatian Nazi-allied troops and civilians who were killed at the end of the Second World War. [size=between 50 and 100]

On 12 May 2020, workers from the tourism industry protested in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, by driving empty buses around the city in order to draw attention to their difficult situation brought on by the coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 29 April 2020, locals protested in Foca, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against the construction of a mini hydro power plant that would potentially harm the environment in the area, despite the measures prohibiting gathering. [size=no report]
On 12 April 2020, a tent meant to house those in mandatory quarantine due to coronavirus was set on fire near the border crossing Maljevac, Bosnia and Herzegovina, by an unknown person or persons.

On 10 April 2020, the anti-fascist partisan cemetery in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, was vandalised during curfew. This is also the day that the Independent State of Croatia, a 'fascist' state was established.

On 23 March 2020, a group of migrants and refugees, at least one of whom was Pakistani, were stopped by uniformed men with balaclavas, who the migrants believe were the police, on the Croatian side of the border in Poljane, near Velika Kladusa, Bosnia and Herzegovina, who severely beat and whipped them, before pushing them back into Bosnia. Croatian police deny any involvement.
Mothers of Srebrenica; Women (Bosnia and Herzegovina)
On 11 March 2020, Mothers of Srebrenica gathered in Tuzla, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in order to commemorate the genocide in Srebrenica. [size=no report]

On 10 March 2020, the Republika Srpska entity of Bosnia and Herzegovina prohibited all public gatherings due to coronavirus. Several regions in the Federation have since followed with similar measures, making the measures effectively country-wide.
On 8 March 2020, protesters marched through Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, calling to end violence against women on the occasion of the International Women's Day. [size=no report]

On 8 March 2020, protesters marched through Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, calling to end discrimination against women, violence and invisibility by seeking equal political, social and cultural rights. [size=no report]
On 8 March 2020, protesters marched through Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, calling to end violence against women on the occasion of the International Women's Day. [size=no report]
On 3 March 2020, protesters blocked the entry to landfill in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, not allowing trucks to dispose of medical waste there. [size=no report]
On 1 March 2020, several hundred people protested in Donje Vardiste, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against construction of a mini hydro power plant. [size=several hundred]

On 28 February 2020, a protest was held in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding better solutions for high air pollution. This was a coordinated action in several cities across the Balkans. [size=no report]

On 28 February 2020, a protest was held in Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding better solutions for high air pollution. This was a coordinated action in several cities across the Balkans. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina (2018-); Labour Group (Bosnia and Herzegovina)
On 27 February 2020, police officers protested in Bihac, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding higher wages. [size=no report]

On 22 February, approximately 100 locals protested in front of a landfill in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and blocked the entrance to the landfill because it does not have the necessary permits to operate. [size=approximately 100]
On 15 February, locals protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against a landfill being moved to their area. [size=no report]

On 15 February, a group commemorating the partisans at the cemetery in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, was attacked by a mob that threw bottles and rocks at them. Graffiti with fascist symbols was also sprayed on the cemetery walls. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina (2018-)

On 15 February, police clashed with hundreds of migrants who were attempting to leave the camp in Velika Kladusa, Bosnia and Herzegovina, near the Croatian border. People protested over conditions at the facility and treatment by Croatian police. [size=hundreds]
Former Military Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina (2018-)
On 14 February, approximately 20 war veterans protested against the new law that they claim abuses their rights in Siroki Brijeg, Bosnia and Herzegovina. [size=approximately 20]

On 14 February, around 3000 protesters gathered in Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, to show support for the Mayor. Earlier in the week, several protests were held because the city has still not adopted a budget. [size=around 3000]

On 12 February, approximately 30 women who have recently given birth protested in Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, because the city still does not have this year's budget so they are unable to receive financial aid. [size=approximately 30]
On 10 February, workers of a bus company protested in Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, because the city still hasn't adopted its budget and the future of their company is uncertain. [size=no report]

On 8 February, hundreds protested in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, to mark four years since the death of Dzenan Memic, a civilian who died in 2016 under the circumstances that remain unclear. [size=hundreds]
On 7 February, a group of citizens gathered in Tuzla, Bosnia and Herzegovina, to mark 6 years from the mass protests that started in that town. [size=no report]

On 6 February, more than 2,000 people protested in Bratunac, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in solidarity with those protesting in Montenegro against the Religious Freedom Act. The (Serbian) Orthodox Church feels unfairly targeted by the new law. [size=more than 2,000]
Orthodox Christian Group (Bosnia and Herzegovina); Students (Bosnia and Herzegovina)

On 3 February, more than 1000 people protested in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in solidarity with those protesting in Montenegro against the Religious Freedom Act. The (Serbian) Orthodox Church feels unfairly targeted by the new law. The protest was organized by students. [size=more than 1,000]
On 30 January, employees of the Croatian Post Office protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, due to low wages, growing workload, and bad management. [size=no report]
On 27 January, parents of Bosniak children protested outside the school in Srebrenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, after a picture of Serbian students celebrating Chetniks surfaced. [size=no report]
On 26 January, a protest was held in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against a landfill that does not have the documentation necessary to operate. [size=no report]

On 22 January, protesters from the 'Because It Concerns Us' initiative blocked the entrance of a landfill in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, because the landfill does not have the documentation necessary to operate [size=no report]
On 20 January, approximately 50 people protested in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding better measures against air pollution. [size=approximately 50]

On 19 January, around 100 protesters from 'Because It Concerns Us' initiative gathered in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in order to protest a landfill that does not have documentation necessary to operate. [size=around 100]
On 19 January, a protest was held near the railway in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, calling for better safety after two people were killed. [size=no report]

On 19 January, a protest was held in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, as a show of support for those protesting in Montenegro against the Religious Freedom Law which the (Serbian) Orthodox Church feels targets them unfairly. [size=no report]
On 18 January, several hundred people protested in Visegrad, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against construction of a hydro power plant. [size=several hundred]
On 15 January, thousands protested in Bijeljina, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against the new Religious Freedom Law in Montenegro. The law is opposed by the Serbian Orthodox Church. [size=thousands]
On 15 January, approximately 200 citizens protested in Tuzla, Bosnia and Herzegovina, against air pollution, demanding the officials take measures against it. [size=approximately 200]

On 13 January, a window was broken and facade damaged on a mosque in Dubica, Bosnia and Herzegovina. The mosque, in the Serbian entity of Bosnia was destroyed during the war and is due to open in the summer after reconstruction.
On 13 January, workers of the 'Euro Profil' company protested in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, after their director and investor who owes them money for wages was arrested. [size=no report]
On 12 January, protesters marched through Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in support of Uyghur Muslims in China. [size=no report]
Mothers of Srebrenica; Women (Bosnia and Herzegovina)

On 11 January, 'Mothers of Srebremica' protested in Tuzla, Bosnia and Herzegovina because remains of some of their children killed in the Srebrenica genocide in 1995 have still not been found. [size=no report]

On 07 January, more than 100 workers of the bus company 'Zenicatrans' marched through Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina because the company is going bankrupt. They have been on strike for a week. [size=more than 100]
On 05 January, a protest was held in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina in front of a waste fill that does not have the necessary permits to operate. [size=no report]

On 04 January, approximately 100 protested in Brcko, Bosnia and Herzegovina, demanding life imprisonment sentence be brought back after a brutal murder of a young man in November. [size=approximately 100]
On 29 December, several hundred protested in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina against a landfill that does not have the necessary documentation to operate [size=several hundred]

On 29 December, a protest was held in Pale, Bosnia and Herzegovina against the adoption of the new Religious Freedom Law in Montenegro . The law is primarily opposed by (Serbian) Orthodox Christians. [size=no report]

On 29 December, several hundred protested in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina against the new Religious Freedom Law passed in Montenegro . The law is primarily opposed by (Serbian) Orthodox Christians. [size=several hundred]
SNSD: Alliance of Independent Social Democrats

On 26 December, hundreds protested in Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina after an oppositional MP from PDP was slapped during a parliament session. Hundreds also attended the counter-protest in support of the government at the same time and at the same place [size=approximately 1000].

On February 24, 2018 in Tetovo near Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina parents of elementary school students organized a protest against unsuitable working conditions in the current school building, and delay in the construction of the new school building.

On February 22, 2018 the police agencies in Bosnia and Herzegovina were placed in the highest state of combat readiness, as a preventative measure after a suicide attack on the US embassy in Podgorica, Montenegro.

On February 22, 2018 in Tuzla, Bosnia and Herzegovina, owners of the apartments in the unfinished '15. maj' building protested the 9-year delay in the construction of the building, demanding the apartments to be usable by May.
On February 19, 2018 in Bihac, Bosnia and Herzegovina an explosive device exploded under a car of a private citizen.

On February 15, 2018 in Tuzla, Bosnia and Herzegovina citizens protested a nine-year delay in the construction of the apartments they already pre-paid in front of the seat of the city administration.

The border police of BiH reported it detained several hundred refugees crossing into BiH at unspecified locations in the north bordering Croatia and in the southeast bordering Serbia. No violence was reported. In February, the reported number of detained refugees was 315 in total.

On February 02, 2018 in Bosnian capital Sarajevo citizens organized a walking protest because of the unresolved death of youngster Dzenan Memic.

On February 2, 2018 in Sarajevo settlement of Otoka in Bosnia and Herzegovina, journalist Nedzad Latic was assaulted by an alleged member of the Wahhabi movement in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as claimed by Latic.
On February 2, 2018 in Zavidovici, Bosnia and Herzegovina citizens blocked the traffic protesting unresolved issues with workers' dues in 'Krivaja' company.
On February 1, 2018, workers of hotel 'Ero' held a peaceful protest in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina over unresolved status of employees of the hotel that was shut down in 2017.
On January 29, 2018, a hand grenade exploded in Old Town, Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina. According to the police records, the aim of the grenade was a private house.

On January 25, 2018, a group of workers of Zenica Steelworks has blocked the M-17 main road in Blatusa, Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina after a clash with the police which left 9 workers injured. Workers are demanding payment of salaries and contributions to the pension and disability fund. This was a part of a several-days long demonstration which included a hunger strike as well.

On January 9, 2018 in Blatusa, Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, workers of 'Zenica Steelways' organized a protest blocking a section of M-17 highway. The workers protested their working conditions.
